lines.text: Look Jack, I'm sorry we seem to have got off on rather the wrong foot, but I'd like you to know that I'm only trying to help.
Trying to help? We called for help 30 minutes ago, but your Limey sons of bitches didn't show!
We called for your help 2 years ago, and you've only just arrived!
About the American Squadron. Yes, well, I have made contact. Over.
Thank god!
Any damage, Archie?
Ah, well, one of them has a few tiny little holes in it - pinpricks really. Over.
What about the Luftwaffe?

[Twitches]
Have you made any contact with the enemy, Archie?
Well, actually, I think that was a bit of a false alarm. Erm, there are no enemy aircraft in the area. Over.
What does he mean, no enemy aircraft - one of my planes just got turned into a tea strainer!
Sorry, Archie, we don't quite understand you, old boy. The American captain reported being under attack. Over.
Ah, yes, it wasn't an enemy aircraft. It was, sort of, in a manner of speaking, me. Over.

[Shocked]
He shot my plane?
Archie, why don't you come in now. Sort of land. perhaps we could have a little chat.
You don't mind if I call you Joe
Not in the least, but my name's Jack
Ah! Even Better! My name's Cyril

Charles, I'll make one last appeal to your better nature! We don't have to go through with this rediculos party. There's still time to cancel the Americans, and just let the nice people come! We could say there's illness in the house - some of the staff have come down with something those type of people go down with.
Oh no - I'm looking forward to this evening!
I don't particularly care, Daphne!

Mother, What's the point of holding an independence Day party without some Americans? Look, the Americans are sharing our base with us. I thought the least I could do was to offer them some English hospitality
I feel exactly the same, darling, but not here! Well, at least cancel your squadron!
Too late, mother - I've invited everyone now!
You seem to be forgetting I have maids working here - young, country girls, who are at an impressionable age. I can't expose them to American airmen!
Mother, they're no different from their British counterparts.
Is that supposed to make me feel better?
[Spots Butler standing nearby]
Do you have any experience with Americans, Butler?

Very Little, Madam. During the First World War, my sister Violet made the aquaintance of a young Americam airman named Hank. I met him on several occasions. He left me with a lasting impression, and Violet with twins.
There, you see - what did I tell you?
Nobody's going to get pregnant, Beatrice!
Don't put it past me, old girl - a couple of medium sherrys, and I'm a tiger!
Your cousin Rosemary will be here!
Yes, well, I'm sure we won't have a repitition of last time.
Of course not! Anyway, Archie bunting won't even be here - he's still in hospital!
Well, actually, he was discharged this morning.
[Butler exits via the door in the background]
Oh look, mother, why do you always look on the black side? I guarantee it will be a very quite, and very civilised gathering.
[a housemaid enters]
Begging your pardon, M'lady. That was Col Hewitt, phoning from the American airbase. He said the band's on it's way.
Dear god!
There is a war on, Bunting!
Oh, Is that what it is! I wondered why the Luftwaffe were shooting down my planes and bombing the shite out of the country!
Hey, little friend, this is your big buddy, we owe you a big one. Over
Honestly, it was nothing!

Friendly fire - that's what it's called nowadays. One wonders who could have invented such a ludicrously cosmetic term for such lethal mistakes. In the Britain of 1942, these episodes were offically known in military circles as balls ups, and sadly they happened all to often. And not just to the British. These incidents afflicted both of the opposing forces - and the Germans too, I shouldn't wonder!

[Barker and Hewitt are walking across the field towards the B-17s]
There you are, jack - all safe and sound.
No damm thanks to the RAF!
Bear with me, old boy, it was an honest mistake, Jack - these things happen. I wouldn't say anything about it if I were you.
Don't say anything! One of your fighters almost destroys an American bomber and it's entire crew, and you expect me to keep quite about it?
Just till we get clearance from HQ. You see, in a funny old sort of way, we have to consider morale!
In the last two hours of my life, I have seen my brand new airbase destroyed by German Luftwaffes
[Barker twitches]
and then, as an encore, my squadron's been attacked by the British!
The moment he lands, I want that screwball - what's his name?
Bunting.
I want to see Squadron Leader Bunting in my office!
Of course. Would you prefer to use my office?
Why?
Well, in a funny old sort of a way, you haven't got an office!

[Chasing after Hewitt]
Look, Jack, I realise you don't relish the prospect of sharing a base with us.

[Stops and turns to face Barker]
Whatever gave you that idea?

[Stopping in front of Hewitt]
Oh, just the way that every time it's mentioned, your face takes on the pinched expression of a man with a mackeral up his arse!
You're not related to Walt Disney, are you?

[On Barker's comparing the situation to a marriage]
Let me be completly honest with you, Cryil, I've only know you for a short while, and I don't like you!
But why?
Oh, it's the little things, like the way you keep saying bare with me, and funny old sort of way. It's the way you teitch every time someone mentions the Luftwwaffe!

[Twitches]
I don't

But you know what really ticks me off? It's that superiour, condersending, oh so British manner of yours and, I might add, I didn't apriciate the mackeral line! A marriage? God, if this is a marriage, we're spending the honeymoon with the in-laws! Are you happily married, Cryil?
I was once, Jack.
She walked out on you, huh? Clever woman! Now your wife, I could get along with!
No, she didn't walk out on me, Jack. She was killed in an air raid on London about a year ago!
I'm sorry. I'm sorry.
Not your fault, Jack
I'll see you and Bunting in your office in 10 minutes.
[Walks off]
Right you are, Jack. i'm looking forward to it.

[Walkimg into the office, where Archie is waiting]
Bloody F!, Bloody, bloody F! Would you kindly explain what the hell you thought you were playing at up there?
[Archie starts to reply]
Shut up! And take that rediculous thing out of your lapel!
You really let me down badly this time, Bunting!
I've let you down? May I remind you, sir, that for the last 6 months, my squadron has been fighting one man short!

[Realising Bunting used the mirror on the wall to see his cards]
You Limey... bullshitter!
I'm going to teach that Limey to play cards fairly - with a marked deck of cards!
How's your leg?
Marvellous - can't feel a thing!
Good! I hope you weren't looking forward to the Independence Day party too much, cause by the time I'm finished with you, you're not going to feel much like dancing.
Get on with it, Lenko - I have to catch a bus into town, i'm going to pick up my bike from the garage.

[Watching Archie push his Silver Star across the table]
You can't bet with a Sliver Star! That's an award from the President of the United states!
I've no money left! Besides, you have to beat my hand first.
I can beat your hand!
How do you know?
Call it intuition.
Well, let's put your intuition to the test then, shall we?

[after Lenko wins the game with Archie]
I wish I could cheat like you, Herschel!
It's easy, J. J. - I'll teach you!
[Lenko and the others watch Archie limp towards the pub door]
Hey, what happened to your leg?
Nothing, old boy! Like I said
[Taps it three times with his cane, producing a matalic sound]
Can't feel a thing. See you at the dance!
[Exits]

[In a playful way]
Thank you, sir.
Oh, I think we can dispense with all this 'sir' business, Edna. Call me Wing-Commander. Or as we know each other, you can call me WingCo.
Sorry?
Short for Wing-Commander. All my chaps call me WingCo.
[Drinks his pint]
Yeah, I think I've heard them call you that.
Hmm.
Well it sounded like that.
[Tully eyes look about thinking what Edna is referring to]

[Archie's been drinking, ordered by Barker to go to his quarters, but stops to talk to Hewitt - this is after the 'likewise' part]
Who the hell do you think you are, sir?
[Hewitt stands up from the table]
I'll tell you who the hell I think I am, sir! I'm Squadron-Leader Blotto, Squadron-Bleeding Hunter, Hunt, Blunt, Something! I'm a pilot, sir, and a damn good one. I bid you goodnight.
[Archie turns and leaves the bar knocking into something]
[Hewitt sits down looking at Archie as he stumbles out]

[Getting two whiskeys from the barman]
Thank you, George.
[Walks over to join Hewitt with the drinks]
That Bunting guy, does he always drink that way?
Hm? Oh no, no, no. Usually, he has to be carried out.
Doesn't that worry you?
Sometimes, yes. But then I understand it. I understand them all. I mean, look at them Jack.
[Camera pans over to Archie's squadron, drinking, talking and laughing]

They're just lads. We taught them how to kill before they've learnt how to shave. And most of them believe that their next sortie will be their last one. So no, I'm not unduly worried about their future health. A drink makes more sense than a pension.
[Hewitt smirks in partial understanding]
Take that incident today. Archie believed that your chaps were being attacked by enemy aircraft. As far as he was concerned, he was a lone fighter facing ten, maybe fifteen Messerschmitts.
That's all very well, but...

He still went in, Jack. He still went in. Now couldn't we pass this whole thing off as an honest mistake? I mean nobody can prove there weren't enemy planes in the area because our radar was down. But you could very well easily say, Bunting escorted your squadron home and that would be the end of it. What do you say, Jack? Eh?
Well, I'll think about it Cyrill. I'm promising nothing.
Thank you, Jack. I appreciate that. Bunting may come across as a bit of a, a bit of a wild egg, but I know one thing. If I give that man an order he will follow it. Regardless of the consequences.
[Archie drives off on his motorbike after Barker ordered him to walk home]
Of course he's ex-grammar school which doesn't help!.

[In British hospital]
Hey, how's your leg?
Hurts. That's why I drink to take the pain away.
[Referring to the cognac Archie is drinking on the quiet]
Oh, I thought you just liked it.
This is war, Lenko. Things are rarely simple as they appear.
Boy, I envy you RAF guys.
Really? Why is that?
You've seen real action. That's where I want to be, right in the thick of it. Must be a great feeling.
Oh yes, it's tremendous fun.
[laughs]

Do you know, I've seen some of my best friends blow to pieces right in front my eyes. One of them, what was his name? Ah, Sky Leggit we called him, his plane exploded about a hundred feet above me and a piece of his lower intestine slapped right across the windscreen. Couldn't budge the bugger.
[Lenko's cheerfulness gives way to a sad and solemn look]
I've been to more funerals than a hearse.
[laughs]
Oh, it's tremendous fun.
[Turns serious]
Listen to me, and understand what I'm saying. This is not a holiday, this is war.
I know it's not a holiday! And we don't say 'holiday', we call it a vacation.
Oh, I do beg your pardon. Look around our ward. There are sixteen men in there. Count how many arms and legs. Just what the doctor ordered.

[Eating breakfast in the dining room]
Have you ever thought what a strange name you've got, Butler?
Sir?
Well, your name's Butler.
[laughs]
And you are a butler.
Oh yes, thank you, sir.
Don't you find that odd?

Not in the least. I once knew a man called Driver, who was indeed a driver. and another young gentleman called Plumber, who for a living plumbed. Oddly enough you're not the first person to notice the coincidence between my name and my occupation. A short while ago, another gentleman said exactly the same as you. His name was Pratt.
[Cappy looks away foolishly, another pilot scoffs, Robbie looks confused]

[Clears throat as he approaches Archie and Dougal on the lawn]
Ah-hem. Excuse me, sir. That was a call from your base. Your squadron leave's been cancelled, sir. You're to return forthwith.

[Pained]
Oh no. Thank you, Butler.
[Butler departs]
Right, Dougal. Get the others together and be quick about it.
[Dougal looks shocked, as he is clearly hungover]

[Calling from far away]
Squadron-Leader!

[Archie and Dougal look around to see where she is calling from. Archie spots her on some steps, nudges Dougal]
Lady Billingham, good morning. Thank you for yesterday. Lovely ceremony, very moving.

[Not impressed]
Is that yours?
[Points with her head to Archie's Spitfire gracefully sitting on the ornamental lawn]
Um, I believe it is!
Well, why did you bring it with you?
Well, I need it, it's part of my job.
Who told you, you could land on my grounds?
Charlie.
Charlie?
He's your son.
[Lady Billingham looks pained]
He said, 'there's plenty of land, bring the kite'.

[after Charlie greets Barker, who departs with Archie & Tully, Cappy comes up]
What's all this 'What-oh, Cyrill!'?
He's a family friend, for Pete's sake.
I hate you nobs. What-oh-bloody-Cyrill?
Oh, just bowl the ruddy ball, Cappy, and stop irritating.
[Charlie takes the cricket bat from Cappy and walks away]

[Disgusted muttering tone]
What-oh-bloody-Cyrill!

[Morning after Charlie's wedding in the breakfast room with Archie's squadron in various form of hangovers. Butler walks over to Robbie's sleeping form on the dining table, pulls him up, removes a plate, and let's him drop tp the table, awaking Archie]
Squadron-Leader. Have you eaten, sir?

[Groggily]
What? No...
Can I get you something, sir? Fried egg? Bacon? Black pudding?
No. Nothing. Thank you. Nothing.
[Butler turns to food, and prepares something]
Umm, how did last night's reception go? Did everyone enjoy themselves?
Well, you seemed to be having a wonderful time, sir. Brought a certain, uh, spirit and flair to the occasion. Everyone remarked upon it.

[Worried]
Oh no. What about Charlie? I didn't upset or offend him, did I?
Well, I couldn't say, sir. After you challenged him to a drinking contest, it was rather difficult to gauge his exact mood, sir.
A drinking contest?
Yes. Apparently it's an ancient tradition within your squadron. It was started, umm, what?
[pauses to think]
All about a year ago. Needless to say, Master Charles lost.
[Archie, embarrassed, nods and looks down]

The other members of your squadron, carried him from the marquee, howling his unconscious form above their heads in a simple but rather touching ceremony. Reminiscent to some long-forgotten Nordic ritual. Simply cried out I thought for a longboat and half a dozen Valkyries and we could have been back at the old Royal Opera House, Vienna. Have you seen Wagner's 'Gotterdammerung', sir?
No.
No, me neither. Thought I did see 'Fasswaller' once at the Finsbury Park Empire.
What about the bride?
I didn't spot her, sir. But there was a rather large audience.
[Walks over to Robbie, pulls him up and puts a plate of food before him. Robbie's sleeping form begins to drop, Butler pulls him up by the shoulder]
No, I meant, did I offend her?

[pauses, looks around, thinking]
Yes.
[Archie nods and looks pained. Telephone rings]
Excuse me, sir, that may be the telephone.
[Taps Robbie on the shoulder who wakes up, surprised and momentarily confused seeing food before him]
